<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 280, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 806, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 361, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 866, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 858, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 220, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 728, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 83, 99, 103]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 82, 143, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 73, 920, 128]]<|/det|>
Use standard results from the list of formulae (MF19) to find \(\sum_{r = 1}^{n}(3r^{2} + 3r + 1)\) in terms of \(n\), simplifying your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 108, 920, 127]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 621, 89]]<|/det|>
Prove by mathematical induction that, for all positive integers \(n\),

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[373, 96, 662, 125]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\mathrm{d}^{n}}{\mathrm{dx}^{n}}\bigl (x^{2}\mathrm{e}^{x}\bigr) = \bigl (x^{2} + 2nx + n(n - 1)\bigr)\mathrm{e}^{x}. \quad []

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 101, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 97, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 798, 109]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) is given by \(\mathbf{M} = \begin{pmatrix} k & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}\), where \(k\) is a constant and \(k \neq 0\) and \(k \neq 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 114, 144, 133]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 114, 920, 149]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) represents a sequence of two geometrical transformations. State the type of each transformation, and make clear the order in which they are applied. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 254, 751, 274]]<|/det|>
The unit square in the \(x - y\) plane is transformed by \(\mathbf{M}\) onto parallelogram \(OPQR\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 286, 146, 304]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 285, 920, 320]]<|/det|>
Find, in terms of \(k\), the area of parallelogram \(OPQR\) and the matrix which transforms \(OPQR\) onto the unit square. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 485, 144, 504]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 484, 920, 529]]<|/det|>
Show that the line through the origin with gradient \(\frac{1}{k - 1}\) is invariant under the transformation in the \(x - y\) plane represented by \(\mathbf{M}\). [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 660, 92]]<|/det|>
The plane \(\varPi_{1}\) has equation \(\mathbf{r} = \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - 2\mathbf{k} + \lambda (\mathbf{i} - 2\mathbf{j} - 3\mathbf{k}) + \mu (\mathbf{3}\mathbf{i} - \mathbf{k})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 144, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 579, 122]]<|/det|>
Find an equation for \(\varPi_{1}\) in the form \(ax + by + cz = d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 631, 710, 650]]<|/det|>
The line \(l\), which does not lie in \(\varPi_{1}\), has equation \(\mathbf{r} = -3\mathbf{i} + \mathbf{k} + t(\mathbf{i} + \mathbf{j} + \mathbf{k})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 662, 144, 680]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 661, 386, 680]]<|/det|>
Show that \(l\) is parallel to \(\varPi_{1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 661, 920, 680]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 442, 89]]<|/det|>
Find the distance between \(l\) and \(\varPi_{1}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 918, 90]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 470, 180, 488]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[178, 470, 504, 488]]<|/det|>
The plane \(\varPi_{2}\) has equation \(3x + 3y + 2z = 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 503, 655, 522]]<|/det|>
Find a vector equation of the line of intersection of \(\varPi_{1}\) and \(\varPi_{2}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 504, 918, 522]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 78, 94, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 646, 100]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has polar equation \(r = \mathrm{e}^{-\theta} - \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{1}{2}\pi}\), where \(0 \leqslant \theta \leqslant \frac{1}{2}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 109, 144, 128]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 108, 818, 129]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\) and state, in exact form, the greatest distance of a point on \(C\) from the pole.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 109, 920, 128]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 479, 181, 496]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 479, 771, 500]]<|/det|>
Find the exact value of the area of the region bounded by \(C\) and the initial line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 480, 920, 500]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 240, 143, 259]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 240, 601, 259]]<|/det|>
Show that, at the point on \(C\) furthest from the initial line,

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 268, 621, 290]]<|/det|>
\[1 - \mathrm{e}^{\theta -\frac{1}{2}\pi} - \tan \theta = 0\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 303, 643, 322]]<|/det|>
and verify that this equation has a root between 0.56 and 0.57.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 303, 918, 322]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 96, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 76, 559, 102]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has equation \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\), where \(\mathrm{f}(x) = \frac{x^2}{x + 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 112, 144, 131]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 112, 489, 131]]<|/det|>
Find the equations of the asymptotes of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 112, 920, 131]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 141, 917, 560]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 577, 146, 596]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 577, 554, 596]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of any stationary points on \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 577, 920, 596]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 235, 88]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 88]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 675, 146, 692]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 670, 798, 695]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of any stationary points on the curve with equation \(y = \frac{1}{\mathrm{f}(x)}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 675, 920, 692]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 78, 144, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 871, 102]]<|/det|>
Sketch the curve with equation \(y = \frac{1}{\mathrm{f}(x)}\) and find, in exact form, the set of values for which

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 256, 133]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{1}{\mathrm{f}(x)} > \mathrm{f}(x).\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 108, 920, 128]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 73, 567, 90]]<|/det|>
